trans-unit.source: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects
trans-unit.target: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects

trans-unit.source: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects
trans-unit.target: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects

trans-unit.source: .NET, .NET Core
trans-unit.target: .NET, .NET Core

trans-unit.source: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects
trans-unit.target: Using MSBuild to build .NET Core projects

trans-unit.source: The .NET Core tooling is going to [move from project.json to MSBuild based projects](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2016/05/23/changes-to-project-json/).
trans-unit.target: The .NET Core tooling is going to [move from project.json to MSBuild based projects](https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/dotnet/2016/05/23/changes-to-project-json/).

trans-unit.source: We expect the first version of the .NET Core tools that use MSBuild to ship along with the next version of Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: We expect the first version of the .NET Core tools that use MSBuild to ship along with the next version of Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: However, it is possible to use MSBuild for .NET Core projects today, and this page shows how.
trans-unit.target: However, it is possible to use MSBuild for .NET Core projects today, and this page shows how.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that most people targeting .NET Core with *new* projects today use the default tooling experience with project.json because of the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: We recommend that most people targeting .NET Core with *new* projects today use the default tooling experience with project.json because of the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: MSBuild doesn't yet support a lot of the benefits of project.json
trans-unit.target: MSBuild doesn't yet support a lot of the benefits of project.json

trans-unit.source: A lot of the ASP.NET based tooling doesn't currently work with MSBuild projects
trans-unit.target: A lot of the ASP.NET based tooling doesn't currently work with MSBuild projects

trans-unit.source: When we do release the .NET Core tooling that uses MSBuild, it will be able to automatically convert from project.json to MSBuild projects
trans-unit.target: When we do release the .NET Core tooling that uses MSBuild, it will be able to automatically convert from project.json to MSBuild projects

trans-unit.source: You may want to use MSBuild to target .NET Core for existing projects that already use MSBuild that you want to port to .NET Core, or if you are using MSBuild's extensibility in your build for scenarios that are not well supported for project.json projects.
trans-unit.target: You may want to use MSBuild to target .NET Core for existing projects that already use MSBuild that you want to port to .NET Core, or if you are using MSBuild's extensibility in your build for scenarios that are not well supported for project.json projects.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: [Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 RC](https://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/visual-studio-prerelease-downloads#sec1) or higher
trans-unit.target: [Visual Studio 2015 Update 3 RC](https://www.visualstudio.com/downloads/visual-studio-prerelease-downloads#sec1) or higher

trans-unit.source: .NET Core tools for Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: .NET Core tools for Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: NuGet Visual Studio extension [v3.5.0-beta](https://dist.nuget.org/visualstudio-2015-vsix/v3.5.0-beta/NuGet.Tools.vsix) or later
trans-unit.target: NuGet Visual Studio extension [v3.5.0-beta](https://dist.nuget.org/visualstudio-2015-vsix/v3.5.0-beta/NuGet.Tools.vsix) or later

trans-unit.source: Creating a library targeting .NET Core
trans-unit.target: Creating a library targeting .NET Core

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio menu bar, choose **File** | **New** | **Project** and select **Class Library (Portable)**
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio menu bar, choose **File** | **New** | **Project** and select **Class Library (Portable)**

trans-unit.source: New Project
trans-unit.target: New Project

trans-unit.source: Choose a name and location for your project and click **OK**
trans-unit.target: Choose a name and location for your project and click **OK**

trans-unit.source: The "Add Portable Class Library" dialog will appear.
trans-unit.target: The "Add Portable Class Library" dialog will appear.

trans-unit.source: Select **.NET Framework 4.6** and **ASP.NET Core 1.0** as targets and click **OK**
trans-unit.target: Select **.NET Framework 4.6** and **ASP.NET Core 1.0** as targets and click **OK**

trans-unit.source: Portable targets dialog
trans-unit.target: Portable targets dialog

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click on your project and choose **Properties**
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click on your project and choose **Properties**

trans-unit.source: In the **Library** tab of the project properties, click on the **Target .NET Platform Standard** link, and click **Yes** in the dialog that is shown
trans-unit.target: In the **Library** tab of the project properties, click on the **Target .NET Platform Standard** link, and click **Yes** in the dialog that is shown

trans-unit.source: Open the `project.json` file in your project, and make the following changes:
trans-unit.target: Open the `project.json` file in your project, and make the following changes:

trans-unit.source: Change the version number of the `NETStandard.Library` package to `1.6.0` (this is the .NET Core 1.0 version of the package)
trans-unit.target: Change the version number of the `NETStandard.Library` package to `1.6.0` (this is the .NET Core 1.0 version of the package)

trans-unit.source: Add the below `imports` definition inside the `netstandard1.6` framework definition.
trans-unit.target: Add the below `imports` definition inside the `netstandard1.6` framework definition.

trans-unit.source: This will allow your project to reference .NET Core compatible NuGet packages that haven't been updated to target .NET Standard
trans-unit.target: This will allow your project to reference .NET Core compatible NuGet packages that haven't been updated to target .NET Standard

trans-unit.source: Creating a .NET Core console application
trans-unit.target: Creating a .NET Core console application

trans-unit.source: Building a console application for .NET Core requires some customization of the MSBuild build process.
trans-unit.target: Building a console application for .NET Core requires some customization of the MSBuild build process.

trans-unit.source: You can find a sample project for a .NET Core console application called [CoreApp](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab/tree/master/samples/NetCoreSample/CoreApp) in the [corefxlab](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab) repo.
trans-unit.target: You can find a sample project for a .NET Core console application called [CoreApp](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab/tree/master/samples/NetCoreSample/CoreApp) in the [corefxlab](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab) repo.

trans-unit.source: Another good option is to start with [coretemplate](https://github.com/mellinoe/coretemplate), which uses separate MSBuild targets files to target .NET Core instead of putting the changes directly in the project file.
trans-unit.target: Another good option is to start with [coretemplate](https://github.com/mellinoe/coretemplate), which uses separate MSBuild targets files to target .NET Core instead of putting the changes directly in the project file.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to start by creating a project in Visual Studio and modifying it to target .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to start by creating a project in Visual Studio and modifying it to target .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: The instructions below show the minimal steps to get this working.
trans-unit.target: The instructions below show the minimal steps to get this working.

trans-unit.source: In contrast to [CoreApp](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab/tree/master/samples/NetCoreSample/CoreApp) or [coretemplate](https://github.com/mellinoe/coretemplate), a project created this way won't include configurations for targeting Linux and macOS.
trans-unit.target: In contrast to [CoreApp](https://github.com/dotnet/corefxlab/tree/master/samples/NetCoreSample/CoreApp) or [coretemplate](https://github.com/mellinoe/coretemplate), a project created this way won't include configurations for targeting Linux and macOS.

trans-unit.source: In the Visual Studio menu bar, choose **File** | **New** | **Project** and select **Console Application**
trans-unit.target: In the Visual Studio menu bar, choose **File** | **New** | **Project** and select **Console Application**

trans-unit.source: Choose a name and location for your project and click **OK**
trans-unit.target: Choose a name and location for your project and click **OK**

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click on your project, choose **Properties**, and then go to the **Build** tab
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click on your project, choose **Properties**, and then go to the **Build** tab

trans-unit.source: In the **Configuration** dropdown (at the top of the properties page), select **All Configurations**, and then change the **Platform Target** to **x64**
trans-unit.target: In the **Configuration** dropdown (at the top of the properties page), select **All Configurations**, and then change the **Platform Target** to **x64**

trans-unit.source: Delete the `app.config` file from the project
trans-unit.target: Delete the `app.config` file from the project

trans-unit.source: Add a `project.json` file to the project with the following contents:
trans-unit.target: Add a `project.json` file to the project with the following contents:

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click on the project, choose **Unload Project**, then right click again and choose **Edit _MyProj.csproj_**, and make the following changes
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click on the project, choose **Unload Project**, then right click again and choose **Edit _MyProj.csproj_**, and make the following changes

trans-unit.source: Remove all the default `Reference` items (to `System`, `System.Core`, etc.)
trans-unit.target: Remove all the default `Reference` items (to `System`, `System.Core`, etc.)

trans-unit.source: Add the following properties to the first `PropertyGroup` in the project:
trans-unit.target: Add the following properties to the first `PropertyGroup` in the project:

trans-unit.source: Add the following at the end of the file (after the import of `Microsoft.CSharp.Targets`):
trans-unit.target: Add the following at the end of the file (after the import of `Microsoft.CSharp.Targets`):

trans-unit.source: Close the .csproj file, and reload the project in Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Close the .csproj file, and reload the project in Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: You should be able to run your program with F5 in Visual Studio, or from the command line in the output folder with
trans-unit.target: You should be able to run your program with F5 in Visual Studio, or from the command line in the output folder with
